questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is diagnosed with a large, invasive adenocarcinoma of the splenic flexure of the colon. The colorectal surgeon recommends surgical resection. Which of the following colectomy procedures would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Extended left hemicolectomy

 

Explanation:

Extended left hemicolectomy is the most appropriate procedure as this involves removing the left side of the colon, including the splenic flexure. Distal 2/3rd of transverse colon, splenic flexure, descending colon, portion of sigmoid colon are removed in extended left hemicolectomy.

 

Type of Colectomy

Structures removed

Total Colectomy

Removal of entire colon

Total Proctocolectomy

Total Colectomy + removal of rectum

Subtotal Colectomy

Removal of entire colon except the rectum

Right Hemicolectomy

Terminal ileum, cecum, ascending colon, hepatic flexure, right half of transverse colon

Extended Right Hemicolectomy

Terminal ileum, cecum, ascending colon, hepatic flexure, proximal 2/3rd of transverse colon

Left Hemicolectomy

Distal 1/3rd of transverse colon, splenic flexure, descending colon, portion of sigmoid colon

Extended Left Hemicolectomy

Distal 2/3rd of transverse colon, splenic flexure, descending colon, portion of sigmoid colon

Transverse Colectomy

Removal of the transverse colon

Sigmoid Colectomy

Removal of the sigmoid colon

Left hemicolectomy (Option A) would not be sufficient, as the tumor appears to be invading adjacent organs.

 

Subtotal colectomy (Option C) may remove the involved segment, but would not address the locally advanced nature of the tumor.

 

Total proctocolectomy (Option D) is too extensive, as the cancer is limited to the splenic flexure.

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient is diagnosed with juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS). Which of the following statements accurately describes the management and characteristics of JPS?

choices.text: The initial colonoscopy screening should be started by age 10
JPS is caused by mutations in the SMAD4 or BMPR1A genes
Prophylactic colectomy is indicated only when iron-deficiency anemia is present
Best managed with immediate total colectomy regardless of the number of polyps

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) JPS is caused by mutations in the SMAD4 or BMPR1A genes.

 

Explanation:

JPS is linked to mutations in SMAD4 or BMPR1A genes.

 

Juvenile polyp

Genetics

Autosomal dominant inheritance; Mutations in BMPR1A, SMAD4, or ENG genes

Key Characteristics
  • Hamartomatous polyps in intestines
  • No pigmentation (unlike Peutz–Jeghers syndrome)

Cancer Risk

10% to 38% lifetime risk of colon cancer; Average age of diagnosis: 34 years

Clinical Diagnosis
  • At least five juvenile polyps in the colorectum
  • Multiple juvenile polyps throughout the GI tract
  • Any number of juvenile polyps with a family history of JPS

Symptoms
  • Acute or chronic gastrointestinal bleeding
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Prolapsed rectal polyps
  • Abdominal pain
  • Diarrhea

Screening Recommendations
  • Initial colonoscopy between ages 12 and 15 (Option A)
  • Repeat colonoscopy in 2-3 years if no polyps are found
  • Annual colonoscopies if polyps are found and removed

Surgical Indications (Option D)
  • High-grade dysplasia or cancer presence
  • Polyp burden unmanageable endoscopically

Surgical Options
  • Subtotal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA)
  • Segmental colectomy
  • Total colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA)

Prophylactic Surgery Considerations (Option C)
  • Poor surveillance compliance
  • Family history of colorectal cancer

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with acute lower gastrointestinal bleeding. He is hemodynamically stable but has a significant amount of blood in his stool. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Inpatient colonoscopy

 

Explanation:

The patient is hemodynamically stable with significant bleeding, making an inpatient colonoscopy the next best step to identify the bleeding source.

Lower GI Bleeding

Definition

Bleeding from the GI tract distal to the ligament of Treitz (jejunum to anus).

Causes
  • Diverticular Disease: Pouches in the colon wall.
  • Angiodysplasia: Vascular malformation with dilated, tortuous submucosal veins in the colon.
  • Heyde’s disease: Characterized by both aortic stenosis and angiodysplasia.
  • IBD: Inflammation and ulceration.
  • Colonic Polyps: Growths in the colon.
  • Colorectal Cancer: Bleeding, bowel habit changes, anaemia.
  • Infectious Colitis: Bloody diarrhoea, possible perforation.
  • Ischemic Colitis: Reduced blood flow, bleeding in splenic flexure.

Management
  • Active Bleeding with Hypovolemic Shock: CT angiogram, embolisation, inpatient colonoscopy, therapeutic endoscopy/surgery.
  • Significant Bleeding without Hypovolemic Shock: Inpatient colonoscopy, EGD, capsule endoscopy/CT angiogram/nuclear medicine scanning.
  • Minor Bleeding: Outpatient investigations.
  • General Considerations: Withhold anticoagulants, transfuse blood products as needed.

Treatment Specifics
  • Angiodysplasia: CT angiography, embolisation, colonoscopy, argon laser, surgery if severe.
  • Diverticular Disease: High-fiber diet, laxatives, antibiotics, surgery for complications.

Importance of Accurate Diagnosis

Differentiating between diverticular bleeding and angiodysplasia is crucial for appropriate treatment. Early diagnosis improves outcomes.

 

Outpatient colonoscopy (Option A) is not appropriate given the significant bleeding.

 

Surgery (Option B) is reserved for cases where less invasive methods fail.

 

CT angiogram (Option C) is more useful for active, severe bleeding or if the patient is in shock.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and low-grade fever. Her medical history includes hypertension and a recent episode of congestive heart failure. An abdominal CT scan reveals signs of bowel ischemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ischemic colitis

 

Explanation:

Ischemic colitis typically presents with sudden abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and systemic signs like low-grade fever, especially in older adults with underlying cardiovascular conditions. The CT findings and symptoms align with this diagnosis.

 

Ischemic Colitis

Definition

Ischemic colitis is the most common form of gastrointestinal ischemia. It occurs when there is insufficient blood flow to the colon, leading to tissue injury.

Causes
  • Thrombotic occlusion: Often linked to atherosclerosis; presents with abdominal pain, raised white cell count, and rectal bleeding.
  • Embolic events: Can cause acute ischemia with severe pain, bloody diarrhea, and hemodynamic instability.
  • Low-flow states: Conditions like septic shock, heart failure, and hypotension increase the risk.

Risk Factors
  • Predominantly affects older adults, women, and individuals with comorbidities.
  • Increased risk in case of atherosclerosis, abdominal surgeries, certain medications, and illicit drug use.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Sudden abdominal pain, tenesmus, bloody diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, low-grade fever, abdominal distension, and tenderness.
  • Mild cases may have nonspecific symptoms; severe cases can lead to shock and require urgent treatment.

Diagnosis
  • Imaging:
    • Abdominal plain films may show "thumb-printing";
    • CT scans with contrast are preferred.
  • Colonoscopy: Gold standard for diagnosis, showing characteristic mucosal changes.
  • Vascular Imaging: Used in suspected acute mesenteric ischemia.

Treatment
  • Conservative Management: Includes bowel rest, IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and addressing underlying conditions.
  • Surgical Intervention: Necessary for severe cases; involves removing gangrenous bowel and ensuring adequate blood supply.

 

Acute mesenteric ischemia (Option A) involves more severe, rapidly progressing symptoms and often requires urgent surgical intervention, but it is less common than ischemic colitis.

 

Diverticulitis (Option C) usually presents with left lower quadrant pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits, but without the sudden onset of bloody diarrhea.

 

Crohn's disease (Option D) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that tends to present with intermittent bouts of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss over time, rather than a sudden onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a 5-day history of watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and low-grade fever. He was recently treated with cephalosporins for a respiratory infection. Upon examination, the patient is dehydrated but stable. Endoscopy reveals raised yellowish-white plaques on the colonic mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pseudomembranous colitis

 

Explanation:

The patient’s recent antibiotic use, clinical symptoms, and endoscopic findings of raised yellowish-white plaques strongly suggest pseudomembranous colitis, which is typically caused by Clostridium difficile infection.

 

Pseudomembranous Colitis

Cause
  • Primarily caused by Clostridium difficile infection.
  • Often associated with antibiotic use, especially cephalosporins.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever.
  • Severe cases: Pseudomembranous colitis with raised, yellowish-white plaques on colonic mucosa.
  • Nonspecific colitis or fulminant colitis may also occur, with a higher risk of perforation.

Diagnosis
  • Based on clinical symptoms and stool tests for C. difficile toxins, antigens, or bacteria.
  • Flexible sigmoidoscopy for inconclusive stool tests or excluding other causes.
  • Colonoscopy used cautiously in fulminant colitis.

Treatment
  • Antibiotics: Oral vancomycin, fidaxomicin, or metronidazole.
  • Fecal microbiota transplantation for unresponsive cases.
  • Emergency subtotal colectomy and ileostomy for severe cases.

Prevention
  • Isolation of suspected cases.
  • Use of protective equipment by healthcare staff.
  • Thorough disinfection and meticulous hand hygiene.

 

Ulcerative colitis (Option A): Typically presents with bloody diarrhea and does not usually show the raised plaques seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

 

Crohn’s disease (Option B): Involves the entire GI tract and often has skip lesions and granulomas on biopsy, which differ from the findings in pseudomembranous colitis.

 

Ischemic colitis (Option D): Usually presents with sudden onset of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea, often in older adults with cardiovascular risk factors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman, recently diagnosed with colon and bladder cancer, presents with a notable family history; her mother also had both cancers and succumbed to them. Additionally, she has a history of sebaceous adenomas. Which other malignancy should she be evaluated for, considering the potential hereditary cancer syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Breast carcinoma

 

Explanation:

Given the patient's history of colonic cancer and the family history of both colonic cancer and bladder cancer, there is a potential risk of a hereditary cancer syndrome such as Muir-Torre Syndrome, a variant of Lynch Syndrome (hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, HNPCC). This syndrome increases the risk of several malignancies, including:

  • Colorectal cancer
  • Bladder cancer
  • Breast carcinoma

 

Muir-Torre Syndrome

Definition
  • A genetic disorder characterised by sebaceous tumours and internal malignancies.
  • Variant of Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer).

Genetic Basis
  • Mutations in mismatch repair genes: MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, EPCAM.
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant.

Associated Cancers

Sebaceous Tumors

Includes adenomas, carcinomas, and hyperplasia.

Colorectal Cancer

Most common. Diagnosed by colonoscopy and genetic testing.

Genitourinary Cancers

Includes bladder, ureters, and kidneys. Diagnosed with imaging and cystoscopy.

Breast Cancer

Managed with mammography and possibly breast MRI.

Other Cancers

Includes non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

Diagnostic Modalities
  • Genetic Testing: To identify MMR gene mutations.
  • Microsatellite Instability Testing
  • Immunohistochemistry: MMR protein expression.

Management and Counseling
  • Surveillance
  • Preventive measures like prophylactic surgery and lifestyle modifications.
  • Genetic counseling and family testing

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the therapy for colon carcinoma are correct?

 

Statements:


	Chemotherapy is often used in the adjuvant setting after surgery to reduce the risk of recurrence in patients with Stage III colon cancer.
	Immunotherapy is typically used as a first-line treatment for patients with colon cancer who have microsatellite instability-high (MSI-H) or mismatch repair deficiency.
	Chemotherapy with FOLFOX (5-Fluorouracil, Leucovorin, and Oxaliplatin) is commonly used for Stage IV colon cancer to achieve a cure.
	Checkpoint inhibitors like Pembrolizumab are effective in colon cancer patients with microsatellite instability-high (MSI-H) or mismatch repair deficiency.
	Radiotherapy is not preferred for colon cancer due to its limited benefit in local control.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 4, and 5

 

Explanation:

 

Chemotherapy Regimens: It is a standard approach for Stage III colon cancer patients after surgery.

 

Indications:

Adjuvant Therapy: Stage III colon cancer, high-risk Stage II colon cancer.

Palliative Therapy: Advanced or metastatic disease.

 

Regimen

Components

FOLFOX
  • 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU)
  • Folinic Acid
  • Oxaliplatin

FOLFIRI
  • 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU)
  • Folinic Acid
  • Irinotecan

CapeOx
  • Capecitabine
  • Oxaliplatin

 

Immunotherapy and Targeted Therapy

 

Indications:

Advanced or Metastatic Disease: Particularly patients with microsatellite instability-high (MSI-H) or mismatch repair deficiency.

 

Category

Drug

Mechanism of Action

Immunotherapy

Pembrolizumab

(Checkpoint inhibitor) PD-1 inhibitor

Nivolumab

PD-1 inhibitor (sometimes combined with Ipilimumab)

Ipilimumab

CTLA-4 inhibitor (sometimes combined with Nivolumab)

Targeted Therapy

Bevacizumab

Anti-VEGF antibody, inhibits blood vessel formation

Cetuximab

Anti-EGFR antibody, effective in KRAS wild-type tumours

Panitumumab

Similar to Cetuximab, fully humanized to reduce allergic reactions

 

Radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not preferred for colon cancer due to its limited benefit in local control.

This is a correct statement. Unlike rectal cancer, where radiotherapy plays a crucial role, it is not typically used in colon cancer treatment. The mobile nature of the colon and its location within the abdominal cavity make radiotherapy less effective and potentially more toxic for surrounding organs.

 

 

Statement 2 is generally incorrect in the context of being a first-line treatment for colon cancer. Immunotherapy is used for MSI-H cases, but typically after initial treatments.

 

Statement 3 is incorrect; FOLFOX is used for Stage III to manage the disease, but it is not commonly used with the goal of achieving a cure in Stage IV colon cancer, where the focus is more on palliation and control.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male underwent a right hemicolectomy for carcinoma of the colon. On the fourth postoperative day, he developed severe abdominal pain, fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. On physical examination, his abdomen is distended and diffusely tender with guarding and rigidity. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals free fluid and air in the peritoneal cavity. Considering the clinical presentation and imaging findings, what is the most likely cause of his current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anastomotic leak

 

Explanation:

  • Anastomotic leak is a serious complication after colorectal surgery and is characterized by leakage of bowel contents at the site of the surgical anastomosis. This can lead to peritonitis, which explains the patient’s severe abdominal pain, fever, and signs of sepsis. The CT findings of free air and fluid are also consistent with this diagnosis.
  • Timing: Anastomotic leaks typically present 3-7 days after surgery, fitting with this patient's presentation on the fourth postoperative day.
  • Clinical signs: The patient's severe abdominal pain, fever, tachycardia, and hypotension are consistent with peritonitis and developing sepsis, which can result from an anastomotic leak.
  • Physical examination: The distended, diffusely tender abdomen with guarding and rigidity strongly suggests peritoneal inflammation.
  • Laboratory findings: An elevated white blood cell count indicates a significant inflammatory response.
  • Imaging: The CT scan showing free fluid and air in the peritoneal cavity is highly suggestive of a perforation, which is most likely due to an anastomotic leak in this post-surgical context.

 

Complications of Colorectal Surgery:

  1. Bleeding
  2. Infection
  3. Anastomotic Leak
  4. Abscesses
  5. Recurrence
  6. Bowel Obstruction
  7. Urinary Retention
  8. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
  9. Nerve Injuries

 

Nerve injuries associated with colorectal surgery

Surgical Procedure

Level of Injury

Nerve Injured

Clinical Features

High Inferior Mesenteric Artery (IMA) Ligation

Near sacral promontory

Superior Hypogastric Plexus

Retrograde ejaculation in men due to sympathetic dysfunction

Division of Lateral Stalks Close to Pelvic Sidewall

Lateral stalks near pelvic sidewall

Pelvic Plexus & Nervi Erigentes

Erectile dysfunction, impotence, and atonic bladder

Anterior Dissection

Periprostatic region

Periprostatic Plexus

Sexual dysfunction and bladder dysfunction (e.g., incontinence)

Low Anterior Resection

Pelvic splanchnic nerves

Pelvic Splanchnic Nerves

Urinary incontinence and bowel dysfunction

Total Mesorectal Excision (TME)

Within the mesorectum

Autonomic nerves within the mesorectum

Erectile dysfunction in men, urinary incontinence

 

Surgical site infections (Option A) can cause fever and leukocytosis postoperatively, they are less likely to present with acute peritonitis, free air, and fluid in the abdomen as seen in this patient.

 

Bowel obstruction (Option C) can cause abdominal pain and distention but typically presents with high-pitched bowel sounds and absence of passage of stool or gas, rather than signs of peritonitis and free air in the peritoneal cavity.

 

Postoperative ileus (Option D) is common after abdominal surgery but is usually characterised by a lack of bowel movement and bowel sounds, rather than the acute peritonitis and sepsis seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight loss, and intermittent abdominal pain. He has a history of occasional rectal bleeding. On examination, he has mild pallor, and there is a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. A colonoscopy is performed, revealing a large ulcerative mass at the hepatic flexure of the colon. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Segmental resection of the hepatic flexure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Extended right hemicolectomy

Explanation:

  • Extended right hemicolectomy involves removing the right colon, including the cecum, ascending colon, hepatic flexure, and a portion of the transverse colon, along with regional lymph nodes.
  • It is the most appropriate surgical approach for a tumor located at the hepatic flexure, ensuring adequate margins and lymph node clearance.

 

Site of Colon Cancer

Surgery Performed

Diagram of Surgery

Cecum & ascending colon

Right hemicolectomy

Segmental resection of the hepatic flexure (Option A) may be considered in selected cases of localized cancer, but it does not provide the necessary margins and lymph node clearance required for curative treatment in this scenario.

 

Right hemicolectomy (Option B) involves removing the ascending colon, it may not include sufficient margins for a tumor located at the hepatic flexure, especially if there's concern about the involvement of nearby structures.

 

Total colectomy (Option D) involves removing the entire colon, which is not indicated in this case unless there are additional risk factors such as widespread polyposis or synchronous tumors that would necessitate such an extensive procedure.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old female with intractable diarrhea and pigmentation was diagnosed with Cronkhite-Canada syndrome. Which of the following statements regarding the disease are true?


	Hamartomatous polyp of colon
	Seen only in females
	Polyps can be present in the stomach and duodenum as well
	15% can turn malignant
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

Cronkhite-Canada syndrome: A rare, non-hereditary syndrome characterised by gastrointestinal polyposis and ectodermal changes.

 

Demographics: Predominantly affects females, typically diagnosed in middle to late adulthood. (Statement 2)

 

Clinical Features:

  • Intractable diarrhoea
  • Cutaneous hyperpigmentation
  • Alopecia (hair loss)
  • Onychodystrophy (nail abnormalities)

Polyp Distribution: Hamartomatous polyps are present throughout the gastrointestinal tract, primarily in the stomach, duodenum, and colorectum. (Statements 1 and 3)

 

Malignancy Risk: Approximately 15% of cases may undergo malignant transformation. (Statement 4)

 

Management: Requires a multidisciplinary approach, including nutritional support, endoscopic surveillance, and treatment of associated complications.

questions.text: Which chemotherapy regimen is standard for adjuvant treatment in a patient with stage III colon cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) FOLFOX

 

Explanation:

Indications of Chemotherapy in colon cancer:

  • HIGH-RISK stage II cancer which includes
    • Bowel obstruction or perforation
    • Perivascular invasion
    • Poorly differentiated tumor
    • < 12 lymph node sampling.
  • Stage III Colon cancer
  • Stage IV Colon cancer

 

STAGE OF COLON CANCER

CHEMOTHERAPY

STAGE III

FOLFOX

  • FOL: Folinic acid (Leucovorin)
  • F: 5-Fluorouracil
  • OX: Oxaliplatin

STAGE IV/Metastatic Colon Cancer

First-line therapy: FOLFIRI

  • FOL: Folinic acid (Leucovorin)
  • F: 5-Fluorouracil
  • IRI: Irinotecan
 

Second line therapy:

  • Bevacizumab - VEGF inhibitor
  • Cetuximab - EGFR inhibitor

 

Capecitabine (Option A): The oral prodrug of 5-Fluorouracil can be used in adjuvant therapy, but it is generally less effective than the FOLFOX regimen.

 

FOLFIRI (Option C): Includes 5-Fluorouracil, Leucovorin, and Irinotecan, which are primarily used in the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer rather than as adjuvant therapy for stage III colon cancer.

 

Bevacizumab (Option D): Monoclonal antibody targeting VEGF and is used in combination with chemotherapy for metastatic colorectal cancer and not used in adjuvant chemotherapy for stage III colon cancer.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female is found to have a 3 cm mass in the ascending colon during colonoscopy. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows no evidence of lymph node involvement or distant metastases. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Perform a right hemicolectomy with en-bloc lymph node dissection.
Recommend adjuvant chemotherapy following the surgical resection.
Proceed with endoscopic mucosal resection of the tumor.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Perform a right hemicolectomy with en-bloc lymph node dissection.

 

Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario, the patient has stage I colon cancer (T1-2, N0, M0) without evidence of metastatic disease.

 

STAGING

TREATMENT

Stage 0 (Tis, N0, M0)

Endoscopic polypectomy

Stage 1 (T1, N0, M0)

Segmental colectomy

Stage 2 (T1-3,N0,M0)

Surgical resection with 5 cm margin and anastomosis

Stage 3 (T any, N1, M0)

Surgical resection + adjuvant chemotherapy

Stage 4 (T any, N any, M1)

Resection of metastases + palliative chemotherapy/radiotherapy

 

Adjuvant chemotherapy (Option B) is typically reserved for stage III colon cancer or high-risk stage II. In this case, there's no evidence of lymph node involvement to justify adjuvant chemotherapy upfront.

 

Endoscopic mucosal resection (Option C) is generally used for early, small tumours (usually < 2 cm) confined to the mucosa or superficial submucosa. The 3 cm size makes this approach less suitable.

 

Endoscopic polypectomy (Option D) is for stage 0 colon cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is a possible description of a T3 colon tumour?

choices.text: Tumour invades adjacent organs or structures

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tumor invades subserosa

 

Explanation:

Stage T3 of colon cancer involves a tumor which invades through subserosa or into pericolorectal tissues.

 

TNM classification of colon cancer:

 

T (Tumor)

Tis

Carcinoma in situ/tumour confined to mucosa (Option D)

T1

Tumour invades the submucosa (Option A)

T2

Tumour invades the muscularis propria

T3

Tumour invades through subserosa or into pericolorectal tissues

T4a

Tumours breach the visceral peritoneum

T4b

Tumor directly invades or is adherent to other organs or structures (Option C)

N (Lymph Node)

N1a

Metastasis in 1 regional lymph node.

N1b

Metastasis in 2-3 regional lymph nodes.

N1c

Tumor deposits in the subserosa, mesentery, or non-peritonealized pericolic or perirectal tissues without regional nodal metastasis.

N2a

Metastasis in 4-6 regional lymph nodes.

N2b

Metastasis in 7 or more regional lymph nodes.

M (Metastasis)

M1a

Metastasis confined to one organ or site

M1b

Metastasis to more than one organ/site or the peritoneum.

M1c

Metastasis to the peritoneum with or without other organ involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Modified Dukes' Staging System for colorectal cancer?

choices.text: Dukes A: Tumour invades the muscularis propria but no lymph node involvement
Dukes B: Tumour penetrates through the muscularis propria with positive lymph nodes
Dukes C: Tumour invades beyond the bowel wall, no lymph node involvement
Dukes D: Tumour has distant metastasis regardless of lymph node status

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dukes D: Tumour has distant metastasis regardless of lymph node status

 

Explanation:

Modified Dukes' Staging System is a classification used to stage colorectal cancer based on the extent of tumour invasion and the presence of lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

 

STAGING

DESCRIPTION

Dukes A

(Option A)

Tumor confined to the mucosa (Stage I in modern TNM staging).

Dukes B

(Option B)
  • B1- Partial penetration of muscularis propria
  • B2- Full penetration of muscularis propria

Dukes C

(Option C)
  • C1- LN involvement without penetration of entire bowel wall
  • C2- LN involvement with penetration of entire bowel wall

Dukes D

(Option D)

Tumor has distant metastasis regardless of lymph node status

questions.text: On barium enema investigation of a 54-year-old male with colon cancer an apple core lesion was found. What is the location of the carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Left

 

Explanation:

  • The "apple core" lesion on barium enema is characteristic of left-sided colon cancer.
  • This appearance is due to the annular, constrictive nature of these tumors, which tend to grow circumferentially around the bowel wall.
  • The narrowed lumen surrounded by the bulging tumor creates an image that resembles an apple core on barium studies.

 

Clinical Features: Colon cancer typically occurs after age 50, with a higher incidence in males.

 

General symptoms:

  • Abdominal pain
  • Altered bowel habits
  • Hematochezia (blood in stool)
  • Anemia
  • Asthenia (weakness) and weight loss
  • Loss of appetite

 

Characteristics

Right-Sided Tumours

Left-Sided Tumours

Location

Cecum, ascending colon, proximal transverse colon

Distal transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon

Growth pattern

Typically polypoid or fungating

Often annular or constricting

Common symptoms
  • Anemia (due to chronic blood loss)
  • Fatigue
  • Weakness
  • Abdominal mass
  • Altered bowel habits
  • Constipation
  • Narrow stools
  • Obstruction

Pain

Less common, vague discomfort

More common, colicky pain

Bleeding

Occult bleeding (melena)

Hematochezia (bright red blood)

Physical exam

Palpable mass in right iliac fossa

Less likely to have a palpable mass

Barium enema finding

Filling defect

"Apple core" lesion

Iron deficiency anaemia

More common

Less common

 

Investigations:

 

  1. Imaging:
  • Barium enema: Shows the "apple core" lesion in left-sided carcinoma
  • Colonoscopy and biopsy: Gold standard for diagnosis
  • Virtual colonoscopy (CT colonography): Visualizes the entire colon
  • CT scan: Evaluates local spread and metastases
  • Ultrasound: Assesses liver metastases and lymph nodes

 

2.Tumor markers:

  • CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen):
    • Normal < 2.5 nanograms per milliliter
    • 5 ng/mL is significant
    • High preoperative levels (> 7.5 ng/mL) indicate poor prognosis
    • Postoperative levels that don't decrease suggest incomplete resection or metastasis

3. Other tests:

  • FNAC of palpable left supraclavicular lymph node
  • Blood tests: Complete blood count, ESR, occult blood in stool
  • Liver function tests

questions.text:
Arrange the steps in the pathogenesis of colon cancer

 


	Dysplasia
	Intermediate adenoma
	DNA methylation
	18q loss DCC
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1,3,2,4

 

Explanation:

Adenoma-carcinoma sequence: The adenoma-carcinoma sequence describes the progression from normal colonic epithelium to colorectal cancer. This process involves a series of genetic and epigenetic changes that occur in a specific order.

 

  1. Dysplasia: This is an early step in the process. Dysplasia refers to abnormal cell growth and organization within the epithelium. It is characterized by hyperproliferation of cells and is considered a precancerous change.
  2. DNA methylation: DNA methylation can silence tumor suppressor genes, contributing to the progression of the adenoma.
  3. Intermediate adenoma: As the genetic and epigenetic changes accumulate, the lesion progresses from an early to an intermediate adenoma. This stage represents a more advanced precancerous lesion.
  4. 18q loss (DCC gene): The loss of the long arm of chromosome 18, which includes the DCC (Deleted in Colorectal Cancer) gene, typically occurs in the transition from intermediate to late adenoma.

 

Therefore, the correct sequence is 1,3,2,4 (Option A)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of long-standing ulcerative colitis presents with rectal bleeding, unintentional weight loss, and altered bowel habits. A colonoscopy reveals a large, ulcerated mass in the sigmoid colon, and a biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. Which of these factors in his history would not have served as risk factors for developing colon cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Use of NSAIDs

 

Explanation:

NSAID is protective against colon cancer, rest are risk factors.

 

Colon cancer:

 

Dietary Risk Factors
  • High red meat (Option D)
  • Low dietary fiber intake
  • High-fat diet
  • Alcohol consumption
  • Cigarette smoking (Option B)
  • Lack of dietary vitamins A, C, E, and zinc

Genetic Risk Factors
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Gardner's syndrome
  • Turcot's syndrome
  • Family history of colon cancer (2-4 times increased risk)
  • Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

Medical Risk Factors
  • Long-standing ulcerative colitis (Option A)
  • Crohn's disease (less risk compared to ulcerative colitis)
  • History of cholecystectomy
  • Ileal resection (increased bile salts)
  • Radiation exposure (mucinous type)
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy (100-500 times increased risk)
  • Acromegaly

PROTECTIVE FACTORS
  • High-fiber diet
  • Dietary calcium
  • Aspirin and other NSAIDs (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate screening method for colon cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Colonoscopy

 

Explanation:

Colonoscopy is considered the most accurate screening method for colon cancer due to its comprehensive nature and therapeutic capabilities.
